recipes.name: Oats Uttapam
ingredients: 2 cups boiled idli rice or short-grained rice, soaked for 4-5 hours
1.5 cups rolled oats, soaked for 4-5 hours
1/2 cup split black lentils (urad dal), soaked for 4-5 hours
1/2 cup carrot, chopped into small cubes
Water, as required for soaking and adjusting batter consistency
Salt, to taste
Oil, for frying uttapams
directions: 1. Wash the idli rice, rolled oats, and split black lentils thoroughly, then soak them in water for 4 to 5 hours or until they swell.
2. Drain the excess water from the soaked ingredients and combine them in a blender. Blend until a smooth and soft batter is formed.
3. If necessary, blend the ingredients in batches to avoid overloading the blender. Transfer the blended batter into a large mixing bowl.
4. Cover the batter and allow it to ferment for 6 to 8 hours at room temperature, or longer if your environment is cool.
5. Once fermented, set aside 1 cup of the batter. Add salt to the reserved batter, mixing well. Store the remaining batter in the refrigerator or freezer for later use.
6. Heat a dosa tava or non-stick frying pan over medium heat. Grease the surface with a few drops of oil, wiping it with an onion or potato slice for even coating.
7. When the pan is hot but not excessively so, pour a scoop of the batter into the center of the pan. Do not spread; instead, scatter the chopped carrot cubes over the batter.
8. Drizzle a little oil over the carrot topping. Cover the pan with a lid to cook the top of the uttapam evenly without needing to flip it.
9. Cook until the edges turn golden and crisp. Gently remove the uttapam with a spatula.
10. Repeat the process with the remaining batter to cook additional uttapams.
11. Serve the oats uttapams hot with coconut chutney and sambar.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Oats Uttapam presented on a rustic wooden board, garnished with fresh cilantro and a side of colorful chutneys. Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the golden-brown crust and the vivid textures of the chopped carrots. Position the camera at a 45-degree angle to showcase the uttapam’s layers, with a shallow depth of field that softly blurs the background, drawing focus to the dish. Include a few scattered oats and lentils around for added texture and interest.

video_script.title: Delicious Oats Uttapam Recipe Tutorial
video_script.description: Learn how to make healthy and delicious Oats Uttapam with this easy tutorial. Perfect for breakfast or a snack!

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully plated Oats Uttapam topped with vibrant carrot cubes, alongside a small bowl of coconut chutney and sambar.
scenes.voice_over: Today, we'll be making a healthy and tasty dish: Oats Uttapam!

scenes.image_prompt: All the ingredients displayed on a wooden kitchen table, with bowls of soaked idli rice, rolled oats, urad dal, and diced carrots, and oil.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, you'll need idli rice, rolled oats, split black lentils, carrots, salt, and oil.

scenes.image_prompt: A close-up shot of idli rice, oats, and lentils soaking in a bowl of water.
scenes.voice_over: First, wash and soak the idli rice, oats, and lentils in water for 4 to 5 hours until they swell.

scenes.image_prompt: A blender filled with soaked ingredients and a smooth, creamy batter being poured into a large bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Drain the soaked ingredients and blend them together to a smooth batter, then transfer it to a mixing bowl.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl covered with a kitchen towel sitting on a countertop, indicating the fermentation process.
scenes.voice_over: Cover the batter and let it ferment for 6 to 8 hours at room temperature.

scenes.image_prompt: A frying pan heated with oil, with a scoop of batter poured in the center.
scenes.voice_over: Once fermented, heat a pan, add a scoop of batter, and sprinkle carrots on top without spreading it.

scenes.image_prompt: A lid placed over the frying pan, with the edges of the uttapam turning golden brown.
scenes.voice_over: Drizzle oil over it and cover the pan to cook until the edges are golden and crisp.

scenes.image_prompt: A spatula gently lifting the golden uttapam from the frying pan onto a plate.
scenes.voice_over: Carefully remove it with a spatula and repeat with remaining batter.

scenes.image_prompt: A table set with a plate of hot Oats Uttapam next to chutneys and sambar, ready to be served.
scenes.voice_over: Serve your Oats Uttapams hot with coconut chutney and sambar for a perfect meal!

cooking_tips: For a creamier texture, add a small amount of yogurt to the batter before fermenting.
Use fresh ingredients for enhanced flavor and nutrition.

recipes.name: Onion Uttapam
ingredients: 1 cup horse gram (Kollu, Kulith), soaked for 4 hours
1 1/2 cups whole urad dal, soaked for 4 hours
1 cup Ponni idli rice (or any variety of short grain rice), soaked for 2 hours
1 teaspoon fenugreek seeds (methi seeds), soaked with urad dal
2 teaspoons oil (for greasing idli plates)
Salt to taste
Water (as needed for soaking, grinding, adjusting batter, and steaming)
directions: 1. Wash and soak the horse gram and urad dal together in water for at least 4 hours, adding the fenugreek seeds.
2. In a separate bowl, wash and soak the Ponni idli rice for at least 2 hours.

3. Grind the soaked horse gram and urad dal separately to a coarse paste, then combine both in a large bowl and mix with your hands. Allow the mixture to ferment for at least 8 hours or preferably overnight.
4. After fermentation, add salt to taste and a little water, if necessary, to achieve a batter-like consistency and mix gently.
5. Prepare a steamer and grease the idli moulds or idli plate with oil.
6. Pour a ladle of the batter into each cavity of the idli mould and steam for at least 15 minutes, or until cooked through. Once done, turn off the flame.
7. Allow the idlis to cool slightly before removing them from the plates and serve warm with chutney or the accompaniment of your choice.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a high-angle shot of a golden-brown Onion Uttapam, showcasing its crispy edges and soft center adorned with vibrant, colorful toppings of finely chopped onions, green chilies, and fresh coriander. Use a rustic wooden table as the backdrop and place the uttapam on a handcrafted ceramic plate. Incorporate a side of coconut chutney and sambar in elegant bowls, while soft, natural light highlights the dish's textures. Use a shallow depth of field to blur the background subtly, creating a warm, inviting mood that emphasizes the dish's inviting colors and details.

video_script.title: Onion Uttapam Recipe Tutorial
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and fluffy Onion Uttapam, a South Indian delight that's perfect for any meal!

scenes.image_prompt: Beautifully plated Onion Uttapam topped with onions, green chilies, and coriander, served with chutney and sambar on the side.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to our Onion Uttapam recipe tutorial! Today, we’ll learn to make this tasty South Indian dish that's perfect for breakfast or a snack.

scenes.image_prompt: Group of ingredients displayed on a wooden countertop: soaked horse gram, urad dal, idli rice, fenugreek seeds, and oil.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, we need one cup of soaked horse gram, one and a half cups of soaked whole urad dal, one cup of idli rice, and fenugreek seeds, along with salt and oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up video of horse gram and urad dal being soaked in water with fenugreek seeds visible.
scenes.voice_over: First, wash and soak the horse gram and urad dal together in water for at least 4 hours, adding the fenugreek seeds to soak.

scenes.image_prompt: A separate bowl with Ponni idli rice soaking in water, getting soft.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, wash and soak the Ponni idli rice for at least 2 hours. This will help in grinding.

scenes.image_prompt: A blender with soaked horse gram and urad dal being ground to a coarse paste.
scenes.voice_over: Grind the soaked horse gram and urad dal separately to a coarse paste. Then, combine both mixtures in a large bowl and mix by hand. Let it ferment for at least 8 hours, or preferably overnight.

scenes.image_prompt: Bowl with fermented batter, hands adding salt and mixing it lightly.
scenes.voice_over: Once fermented, add salt to taste and a little water, if necessary, until you reach a batter-like consistency. Mix gently.

scenes.image_prompt: Steamer setup with idli moulds greased with oil, ready for batter pouring.
scenes.voice_over: Prepare your steamer and grease the idli moulds with oil. This prevents sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: Pouring ladles of batter into idli moulds and placing them in the steamer.
scenes.voice_over: Pour a ladle of batter into each cavity of the idli mould and steam for at least 15 minutes or until they’re cooked through. Make sure to keep the flame steady.

scenes.image_prompt: Removed idlis cooling slightly on a plate, look fluffy and soft.
scenes.voice_over: Once done, turn off the flame and allow the idlis to cool slightly before removing them from the plates.

scenes.image_prompt: Final serving of Onion Uttapam on a plate with a bowl of chutney and sambar.
scenes.voice_over: Serve the Onion Uttapam warm with chutney or the accompaniment of your choice. Enjoy this healthy treat!

cooking_tips: For best results, allow the batter to ferment at a warm temperature.
You can customize the uttapam by adding chopped onions, tomatoes, or other vegetables to the batter before steaming.

recipes.name: Oats Dosa Recipe - A Healthy Indian Crepe
ingredients: 1 cup boiled rice or idli rice, soaked
½ cup split black gram (urad dal), soaked
1 cup quick-cooking oats, soaked
Water as needed to adjust batter consistency
1 teaspoon sugar
Salt to taste
Few drops of cooking oil for frying
directions: Step 1: Soak the boiled rice, split black gram, and oats in sufficient water for 7-8 hours, or until they swell.
Step 2: Drain the excess water and grind the mixture into a smooth batter, adding a little water as necessary to achieve a medium consistency.
Step 3: Cover the batter and allow it to ferment for 7-8 hours or overnight in a warm place. The fermentation process may take longer in colder climates.
Step 4: After fermentation, add salt and sugar to the batter, stirring gently to combine. If the batter is too thick, add a bit more water to achieve the desired consistency.
Step 5: Heat a dosa pan over medium heat, and lightly grease it with a few drops of oil wiped on with a piece of halved onion or a cloth.
Step 6: Pour a ladle of batter into the center of the pan and spread it in a circular motion towards the edges using a spatula or the back of a small bowl.
Step 7: Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges of the dosa. Once the bottom is golden brown, carefully flip and cook the other side.
Step 8: Repeat the process with the remaining batter, adjusting the heat as necessary to avoid burning the dosas. Sprinkle water on the pan if temperatures rise too high.
Step 9: Serve the oats dosa hot with coconut chutney or sambar.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up shot of a golden-brown Oats Dosa, elegantly draped over a vibrant green banana leaf, highlighting its crispy texture. Use natural light to enhance the dosa's warm tones, ensuring soft shadows add depth. Include a small bowl of coconut chutney and a sprinkle of fresh coriander as garnish. Position the camera at a 45-degree angle to emphasize the dosa's edges. Use a shallow depth of field to keep the focus sharp on the dosa while softly blurring the background elements for a refined, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Oats Dosa Recipe - A Healthy Indian Crepe
video_script.description: Learn how to make a delicious and healthy oats dosa, a delightful Indian crepe perfect for breakfast or a snack!

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully plated oats dosa served with coconut chutney and sambar, garnished with fresh coriander.
scenes.voice_over: Today, we’ll make a delicious oats dosa, packed with nutrition and flavor!

scenes.image_prompt: All ingredients neatly arranged on a kitchen counter, including rice, urad dal, oats, and spices.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, you'll need boiled rice, split black gram, quick-cooking oats, sugar, salt, and cooking oil.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl showing boiled rice, urad dal, and oats soaking in water with a timer set for 8 hours.
scenes.voice_over: Soak the boiled rice, urad dal, and oats in water for 7-8 hours until they swell.

scenes.image_prompt: A blender filled with the soaked ingredients being blended into a smooth batter.
scenes.voice_over: Drain the excess water and blend the mixture into a smooth batter, adding water for consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl with white batter covered with a cloth, placed in a warm spot for fermentation.
scenes.voice_over: Cover and let the batter ferment for 7-8 hours or overnight in a warm place.

scenes.image_prompt: Fermented batter in a bowl with salt and sugar being added, ready to be mixed.
scenes.voice_over: After fermentation, mix in salt and sugar, adjusting the thickness if necessary.

scenes.image_prompt: A dosa pan being heated with a drop of oil applied with a piece of onion.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a dosa pan over medium heat, lightly grease it with oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Dosa batter being poured and spread on the pan into a circular shape.
scenes.voice_over: Pour a ladle of batter onto the pan and spread it in a circular motion.

scenes.image_prompt: A dosa frying in the pan with oil sizzling around the edges.
scenes.voice_over: Drizzle oil around the edges and cook until the bottom is golden brown, then flip.

scenes.image_prompt: A stack of crispy oats dosas on a plate with water being sprinkled on the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Continue until all batter is used, adjusting heat as needed. Serve hot.

scenes.image_prompt: Final presentation of oats dosa with chutney and sambar on the side, garnished with coriander.
scenes.voice_over: Enjoy your delicious oats dosa with coconut chutney or sambar. A healthy delight!

cooking_tips: Ensure that the batter is not too thick; it should easily spread in the pan.
You may add finely chopped vegetables to the batter for added nutrition.
Keep the dosa pan well-greased to prevent sticking.
